column1: West Palm Beach is a city in and the county seat of Palm Beach County
column2: Florida
column3: United States. It is located immediately to the west of the adjacent Palm Beach
column4: which is situated on a barrier island across the Lake Worth Lagoon. The population was 99
column5: 919 at the 2010 census. West Palm Beach is a principal city of the Miami metropolitan area
column6: which was home to an estimated 6
column8: 824 people in 2017.It is the oldest incorporated municipality in the south Florida area
column9: having been incorporated as a city two years before Miami in November 1894. West Palm Beach is located approximately 68 miles (109 km) north of Downtown Miami.

column1: The beginning of the historic period in south Florida is marked by Juan Ponce de León's first contact with native people in 1513. Europeans found a thriving native population
column2: which they categorized into separate tribes: the Mayaimi in the Lake Okeechobee Basin and the Jaega and Ais people in the East Okeechobee area and on the east coast north of the Tequesta. When the Spanish arrived
column3: there were perhaps about 20
column4: 000 Native Americans in south Florida. By 1763
column5: when the English gained control of Florida
column6: the native peoples had all but been wiped out through war
column7: enslavement
column8: or European diseases.Other native peoples from Alabama and Georgia moved into Florida in the early 18th century. They were of varied ancestry
column9: but Europeans called them all "Creeks." In Florida
column10: they were known as the Seminole and Miccosukee Indians. The Seminoles clashed with American settlers over land and over escaped slaves who found refuge among them. They resisted the government's efforts to move them to the Indian Territory west of the Mississippi River. Between 1818 and 1858
column11: three wars were fought between Seminoles and the United States government. By 1858
column12: there were very few Seminoles remaining in Florida.The area that was to become West Palm Beach was settled in the late 1870s and 1880s by a few hundred settlers who called the vicinity "Lake Worth Country." These settlers were a diverse community from different parts of the United States and the world. They included founding families such as the Potters and the Lainharts
column13: who would go on to become leading members of the business community in the fledgling city. The first white settlers in Palm Beach County lived around Lake Worth
column14: which at the time was an enclosed freshwater lake
column15: named after Colonel William Jenkins Worth
column16: who had fought in the Second Seminole War in Florida in 1842. Most settlers engaged in the growing of tropical fruits and vegetables for shipment to the north via Lake Worth and the Indian River. By 1890
column17: the U.S. Census counted over 200 people settled along Lake Worth in the vicinity of what would become West Palm Beach. The area at this time also boasted a hotel
column20: and a post office. The city was platted by Henry Flagler as a community to house the servants working in the two grand hotels on the neighboring island of Palm Beach
column22: coinciding with the arrival of the Florida East Coast railroad. Flagler paid two area settlers
column26: stretching from Clear Lake to Lake Worth.

column3: 78 people met at the "Calaboose" (the first jail and police station located at Clematis St. and Poinsettia
column4: now Dixie Hwy.) and passed the motion to incorporate the Town of West Palm Beach in what was then Dade County (now Miami-Dade County). This made West Palm Beach the first incorporated municipality in Dade County and in South Florida. The town council quickly addressed the building codes and the tents and shanties were replaced by brick
column5: brick veneer
column6: and stone buildings. The city grew steadily during the 1890s and the first two decades of the 20th century
column7: most residents were engaged in the tourist industry and related services or winter vegetable market and tropical fruit trade. In 1909
column8: Palm Beach County was formed by the Florida State Legislature and West Palm Beach became the county seat. In 1916
column9: a new neo-classical courthouse was opened
column10: which has been painstakingly restored back to its original condition and is now used as the local history museum.

column1: The city grew rapidly in the 1920s as part of the Florida land boom. The population of West Palm Beach quadrupled from 1920 to 1927
column2: and all kinds of businesses and public services grew along with it. Many of the city's landmark structures and preserved neighborhoods were constructed during this period. Originally
column3: Flagler intended for his Florida East Coast Railway to have its terminus in West Palm
column4: but after the area experienced a deep freeze
column5: he chose to extend the railroad to Miami instead.

column1: The land boom was already faltering when city was devastated by the 1928 Okeechobee hurricane. The Depression years of the 1930s were a quiet time for the area
column2: which saw slight population growth and property values lower than during the 1920s. The city only recovered with the onset of World War II
column3: which saw the construction of Palm Beach Air Force Base
column4: which brought thousands of military personnel to the city. The base was vital to the allied war effort
column5: as it provided an excellent training facility and had unparalleled access to North Africa for a North American city. Also during World War II
column6: German U-Boats sank dozens of merchant ships and oil tankers just off the coast of West Palm Beach. Nearby Palm Beach was under blackout conditions to minimize night visibility to German U-boats.

column1: The 1950s saw another boom in population
column2: partly due to the return of many soldiers and airmen who had served in the vicinity during the war. Also
column3: the advent of air conditioning encouraged growth
column4: as year-round living in a tropical climate became more acceptable to northerners. West Palm Beach became one of the nation's fastest-growing metropolitan areas during the 1950s; the city's borders spread west of Military Trail and south to Lake Clarke Shores. However
column5: many of the city's residents still lived within a narrow six-block wide strip from the south to north end. The neighborhoods were strictly segregated between White and African-American populations
column6: a legacy that the city still struggles with today. The primary shopping district remained downtown
column7: centered around Clematis Street.

column2: Palm Beach County's first enclosed shopping mall
column3: the Palm Beach Mall
column4: and an indoor arena were completed. These projects led to a brief revival for the city
column5: but in the 1970s and 1980s crime continued to be a serious issue and suburban sprawl continued to drain resources and business away from the old downtown area. By the early 1990s there were very high vacancy rates downtown
column6: and serious levels of urban blight.

column2: developments such as CityPlace and the preservation and renovation of 1920s architecture in the nightlife hub of Clematis Street have seen a downtown resurgence in the entertainment and shopping district. The city has also placed emphasis on neighborhood development and revitalization
column3: in historic districts such as Northwood
column4: Flamingo Park
column5: and El Cid. Some neighborhoods still struggle with blight and crime
column6: as well as lowered property values caused by the Great Recession
column7: which hit the region particularly hard. Since the recovery
column8: multiple new developments have been completed. The Palm Beach Mall
column9: located at the Interstate 95/Palm Beach Lakes Boulevard interchange became abandoned as downtown revitalized - the very mall that initiated the original abandonment of the downtown. The mall was then redeveloped into the Palm Beach Fashion Outlets in February 2014. The West Palm Beach station for Brightline
column10: a high speed passenger rail service serving Miami

column1: According to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
column2: the West Palm Beach Canal (C-51)/Stormwater Treatment Area (STA)1 East project was authorized by the U.S. Congress under the Flood Control Acts of 1948
column6: and the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 1996. The project is located in Palm Beach County and runs east to west from West Palm Beach at Lake Worth to Water Conservation Area (WCA) No. 1 (Loxahatchee National Wildlife Refuge). The authorized project will provide 30-year flood protection to the urbanized eastern basin and 10-year flood protection to the western basin. All eastern basin features have been completed.During mediation of the Everglades water quality litigation
column7: a technical plan was developed for resolution of the litigation. The technical plan included a substantially modified C-51 project. The modified plan expands the original 1
column8: 600-acre floodwater detention area into a 6
column9: 500-acre stormwater detention area. In addition to the flood damage reduction benefits provided by the original project
column10: the modified plan provides water treatment
column11: reduction of damaging freshwater discharges to Lake Worth
column12: and increased water supply for the Everglades and other users.According to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
column13: the total estimated cost of the West Palm Beach Canal (C51) is $375.47 million
column14: with an estimated $345.04 million as the Federal Government's cost share. A total of $1.05 million was appropriated for this project by the U.S. Congress in Fiscal Year 2015. The Fiscal Year 2016 Budget Request from the U.S. President to the U.S. Congress was for $1 million.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: this city has a total area of 58.2 square miles (151 km2)
column3: of which 55.1 square miles (143 km2) is land and 3.1 square miles (8.0 km2) (5.26%) is water.

column1: Due to vast areas of wetland immediately to the west of the city's downtown
column2: growth took place to the north and south in a linear fashion. Until the 1960s
column3: the city was no more than several blocks wide but over 100 blocks in length. Large scale development finally expanded to the west of the city with improved access and drainage in the 1960s. However
column4: the city boundaries were not expanded much with the exception of the "Water Catchment Area"
column5: an uninhabited area in the northwest part of the city. Known as Grassy Waters
column6: it now serves as a reservoir for the city drinking water as well as a nature preserve.

column1: Bel Air Historic District: Developed from 1925 to 1935 as a neighborhood for tradesmen and real estate salesmen who helped develop Palm Beach County
column2: some of Belair was originally a pineapple plantation owned by Richard Hone. Hones's frame vernacular house
column3: built around 1895
column4: still stands at 211 Plymouth Road. After Hone was murdered in 1902
column5: his property was sold to George Currie
column6: who created Currie Development Co. But before it was developed
column7: the land was sold to William Ohlhaber
column8: who raised coconut palms and ferns. Eventually
column9: Ohlhaber platted the subdivision and sold off lots. The first house built in the subdivision was Ohlhaber's mission-style home at 205 Pilgrim. Ohlhaber's grandson said Ohlhaber bought the tract to provide dockage for his 90-foot (27 m) yacht
column10: but the yacht ran aground in the Gulf of Mexico and never reached Lake Worth. In 1947 Hone's house was bought by Max Brombacher
column12: and it remains in the Brombacher family today. Belair became West Palm Beach's fourth historic district in August 1993.

column1: Central Park: Central Park is a collective name for several subdivisions north of Southern Boulevard. It originally was part of the Estates of South Palm Beach (which went from Wenonah Place to Pilgrim Road east of Dixie Highway). Like other West Palm Beach neighborhoods
column2: the Estates of South Palm Beach boomed after Henry Flagler's descent on Palm Beach. In 1884
column3: James W. Copp
column4: a bachelor in the boating business
column5: borrowed $367.20 from Valentine Jones to buy the land. The ownership of what is now known as Central Park changed hands many times before being developed. Around 1919
column6: the tropical wilderness was transformed into an exclusive neighborhood with curbed roads
column7: sidewalks and a pier (at the foot of what is now Southern Boulevard). The neighborhood became part of West Palm Beach in 1926
column8: and was named a city historic district in December 1993. In 1999 the neighborhood was listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: El Cid: Noted for its Mediterranean revival and mission-style homes
column2: El Cid developed in the height of Florida's real estate boom. In the late 19th century
column3: most of the land north of Sunset Road was pineapple fields
column4: but the crop dwindled in the early 20th century. Pittsburgh socialite Jay Phipps subdivided the old pineapple fields in the 1920s. He named it El Cid
column5: after the celebrated Spanish hero
column6: Rodrigo Díaz de Vivar
column7: who conquered Valencia in 1094. He was called "Cid"
column8: meaning "lord". El Cid became a city historic district in June 1993. In 1995 the neighborhood was listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Flamingo Park: Originally a pineapple plantation
column2: Flamingo Park was established by local contractors and developers
column3: who saw the potential in this area—one of the highest coastal ridge sections from downtown West Palm Beach to Miami. Some ridge houses even had ocean views from upper floors. Houses cost about $10
column5: 000 in the boom era
column6: and many buyers were owners of shops and businesses on fashionable Dixie Highway nearby. Recently
column7: residents rallied to have stop signs installed throughout the neighborhood and have banded together to ward off commercial and industrial zoning. Property values are rising as residents renovate and restore Spanish-style houses. Most of the homes in the neighborhood
column8: developed from 1921 to 1930
column9: are mission style
column10: but nearly every style is represented. There are many Mediterranean revival-style houses along the high ridge line. Only two buildings in the historic district are known to have been designed by architects: 701 Flamingo Drive designed by Harvey and Clarke
column11: and the Armory Arts Center designed by William Manly King. The neighborhood became a West Palm Beach historic district in January 1993 and was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 2000.

column1: Grandview Heights: One of the city's oldest neighborhoods still intact
column2: Grandview Heights was built as an extension of Palm Beach Heights from around 1910 to 1925. Almost all of Palm Beach Heights and half of Grandview Heights was demolished in 1989 to make way for the proposed Downtown/Uptown project
column3: which became CityPlace. Grandview Heights originally attracted construction workers who helped build the luxury hotels
column4: ministers and store owners. The neighborhood has one of the city's best collection of early craftsman-style bungalows
column5: as well as some modest
column6: Mediterranean revival-style homes. The neighborhood became a West Palm Beach historic district in 1995 and was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1999.

column1: Mango Promenade: Mango Promenade became a West Palm Beach historic district in 1995 and was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1999. Lies just south of Palm Beach Atlantic University.
Northboro Park: An expansion of Old Northwood
column2: Northboro Park was mostly custom houses for upper-middle-class professionals. Most of the houses are Mediterranean revival
column3: mission and frame vernacular. Developed from 1923 to 1940
column4: the neighborhood became the city's second historic district (November 1992) and the historic designation may soon expand north to 45th Street. The oldest building in the neighborhood is Northboro Elementary School at 36th Street and Spruce
column5: built in 1925 by DaCamara and Chace. The demolition of Northboro Elementary School began in late 2009. The first home in Northboro Park is 418 36th St.
column6: built in 1923.

column1: Northwest: West Palm Beach's first historic district to be included on the National Register of Historic Places (February 1992)
column2: the Northwest neighborhood was first settled in 1894
column3: when the black community was moved from the Styx in Palm Beach to West Palm Beach. It also served as the city's segregated black community from 1929 to 1960 (along with Pleasant City). Northwest remains a predominantly black community but according to the city planning department
column4: most middle- and upper-class blacks moved to other neighborhoods after desegregation. Tamarind and Rosemary Avenues were the commercial centers for blacks by 1915
column5: but most commercial buildings have been demolished or remodeled so the architecture is no longer significant. There are still good examples of late 19th- and early 20th-century American bungalow/craftsman-style homes in this neighborhood
column6: which also has mission
column7: shotgun
column8: Bahamian vernacular and American Foursquare styles. The Alice Frederick Mickens house
column9: at 801 Fourth St.
column10: is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Mickens was a philanthropist and humanitarian who promoted education for black youth. Another notable house is the Gwen Cherry house at 625 Division Ave. Cherry
column11: Florida's first black woman legislator and a resident of Miami
column12: inherited the house from relative Mollie Holt
column13: who built the house in 1926. Now it is the Palm Beach County Black Historical Society. The Northwest neighborhood was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1992. The next year the neighborhood became a West Palm Beach historic district in 1993.

column1: Old Northwood Historic District: Old Northwood was developed from 1920 to 1927—the height of the city's real estate boom. The Pinewood Development Co.
column2: platted and developed the area. Old Northwood became a neighborhood of what was considered extravagant Mediterranean revival
column3: mission and frame vernacular houses
column4: at $30
column6: 000. The buyers were professionals
column7: entrepreneurs and tradesmen. Among them was David F. Dunkle
column8: who was mayor of West Palm Beach. There are houses here designed by notable architects John Volk (best known for his Palm Beach houses)
column9: William Manly King (who designed Palm Beach High School and the Armory Arts Center) and Henry Steven Harvey (whose Seaboard Railroad Passenger Station on Tamarind Avenue is listed in the National Register of Historic Places). The neighborhood became a West Palm Beach historic district in 1991 and listed in the National Register of Historic Places in June 1994.

column1: Northwood Hills Historic District: On August 4
column3: the City Commission designated the Northwood Hills neighborhood as the 13th Historic District in the City of West Palm Beach. Northwood Hills comprises the area from 29th Street on the South to 39th Court on the North. The east side of Windsor is the Western boundary
column4: and Greenwood Avenue is the Eastern boundary. The Neighborhood Association has worked several years to achieve the distinction of historic designation. This is the first district to be designated since 1996. Northwood Hills has a number of Mission Revival houses
column5: a significant collection of Post-World War II architecture
column6: a unique street layout
column7: and one of the highest elevations in the city. The Northwood Hills neighborhood has also elected to allow the establishment of Bed and Breakfast establishments within the neighborhood.

column1: Prospect Park: Promoted as a high-end neighborhood patterned after the prominent Prospect Park district in Brooklyn
column2: this area consisted of mostly smaller estates for prominent businesspeople and northern investors. The neighborhood has a high concentration of Mediterranean revival and Mission revival houses. It was developed from 1920 to 1935 and became a city historic district in November 1993.

column1: West Northwood Historic District: Cashing in on the real estate boom
column2: developers of West Northwood built speculative and custom houses for upper-middle-class professionals from 1925 to '27. Dominant architectural styles are Mediterranean revival and mission. Although the area was declining
column3: that has reversed in recent years
column4: as more investors buy and restore the houses. West Northwood became a city historic district in August 1993.

column1: West Palm Beach has a Tropical savanna climate (Köppen Aw) with mean temperatures in all months above 64.4 °F (18 °C). The city
column2: like most of Florida's southeast coast
column3: is situated in USDA hardiness zone 11a.

column1: The wet season—May through October—is hot
column2: humid
column3: and wet. The average window for 90 °F (32 °C) temperatures is February 18 through October 30
column4: but temperatures of 100 °F (38 °C) or higher have only occurred four times since record-keeping began in 1888. During this period
column5: more than half of the days bring afternoon thunderstorms and sea breezes that cool the air for the rest of the day. Late in the season
column6: there is also a chance for a tropical storm or hurricane to strike.

column1: The dry season—November through April—is warm and mostly dry
column2: with 80 °F (27 °C) temperatures remaining fairly commonplace even from December through February. However
column3: the area experiences occasional cold fronts during this period
column4: which typically fizzle out and bring little to no rain. Occasionally
column5: a stronger cold front can lower daytime temperatures to around 70
column6: and nighttime lows to 40-50 degrees for a brief period of time before rebounding to the 75-80 degree range. Freezes are almost all unheard of
column7: the last occurrence in 1977. The dry season can also bring about potential for drought and during hotter
column8: drier seasons.

column1: Air: The city is served by Palm Beach International Airport
column2: located in unincorporated Palm Beach County. The airport attracts people from all over the county as well as from the Treasure Coast and Space Coast counties to the north. In 2014 there were over 6.5 million passengers who passed through the gates of PBIA making it the 52nd busiest airport in the nation.Bicycle The city's flat terrain
column3: early paved streets
column4: and year-round climate quickly earned it the designation as the "bicyclingest town in the U.S.A.". The historic core consists of a dense grid of narrower streets
column5: laid out by Henry Flagler. Clematis Street was one-lane each direction with a speed limit of 12 mph
column6: and the middle of the street between lanes was used to park bicycles. The popularity of bicycling declined during the later half of the 20th century
column7: but has undergone a renewed increase in popularity. In addition

column1: Port: The Port of Palm Beach is located on the northern edge of the city limits. It is the fourth busiest container port in Florida and the 18th busiest in the continental United States. In addition to intermodal capacity
column2: the Port is a major modal point for the shipment of various goods as well as being the home to several small passenger cruise lines.

column1: Violent crime: According to Florida Department of Law Enforcement (FDLE) statistics
column2: West Palm Beach is experiencing a steep drop in major crimes. In the past decade
column3: crime has dropped more in West Palm Beach than in any other major city (approximately 100
column4: 000 residents or more) in the state of Florida. In 1993
column5: West Palm Beach was featured in a 60 Minutes segment on urban decay. At the time
column6: 80% of downtown properties were vacant. Since then
column7: the city has done much to improve its image
column8: at least in the physical sense. Occupancy is high
column9: and housing prices have risen rapidly. FDLE stats show that the total crime rate per 100
column10: 000 residents has dropped by more than 50% since 2000
column14: there was a 17.9% drop in crime. Annual crime rates are always more than three times the national average. However
